newsitem.title: USA: PP&L puts transition costs at $4.6 bln. [CORRECTED 00:30 GMT 2/4]
newsitem.headline: PP&L puts transition costs at $4.6 bln. [CORRECTED 00:30 GMT 2/4]

text.p: Pennsylvanian Power & Light Co said its Tuesday restructuring filing with Pennsylvania regulators estimates transition costs under the plan at $4.6 billion.

"Our projections show PP&L will fail to recover about $400 million of its transition costs," the PP&L Resources Inc subsidiary said. It has deferred a decision on whether or not it will seek to securitieze any portion of the transisition costs approved by regulators, as allowed by Pennsylvania law.
It said the plan, based on charges in effect January 1, 1997, proposes no changes in rate levels.
Pointing out its rates are below the Pennsylvania average PP&L said its filing with the state Public Utility Commission caps rates for four and a half years.
Rates will be unbundled to show three main categories -- transmission and distribution, Generation and competitive transition charges, the utility said.

The CTC, Competitive Transition Charge, will be used to recover transition costs, its statement explained. This charge, which is subject to regulatory approval, is not an increase in rates, "simply a restatement of costs currently paid by customers."

It said most of the projected transition costs result from the construction of the Susquehanna nuclear power plant. Other components include environmental protection equipment for coal-fired plants, power purchases from non-utility generators and accounting-related charges resulting from certain financial and ratemaking practices under regulation.
The utility noted it had expected to recover investments over periods ranging up to 40 years. "With competition coming to the business, that is no longer practical."
Taxes, which will be unchanged under Pennsylvania's restructuring legislation, will be blended in to all three categories, spokesman Dan McCarthy said.
(Corrects from: "The Transmission & Distribution Charge will include a listing of taxes, which will be unchanged under Pennsylvania's restructuring legislation...". Reflects McCarthy's correction).
PP&L said the 4-1/2 year cap applies to distribution rates while it plans a nine year generation cost cap.

PP&L said it plans to participate as a power supplier in its current service territory and elsewhere and is proposing separation of its generation and electricity sales function from the tgransmission and distribution function.

McCarthy said this would result in separate divisions within in the utility -- an unregulated generation and retail energy supply division with "fire walls" separating it from the regulated distribution division.
